Name: IIS Application - Create
Description: Create an IIS virtual application (a virtual directory with an application pool)

Parameters.Name: VirtualPath
Parameters.Label: Virtual path
Parameters.HelpText: The name of the application to create. For example, to serve an application that will be available at `/myapp`, enter `myapp`. To create an application under a parent virtual directory or application, separate with slashes - for example: `/applications/myapp`

Parameters.Name: PhysicalPath
Parameters.Label: Physical path
Parameters.HelpText: Physical folder that the application will serve files from. Example: `C:\MyApp`.

Parameters.Name: ParentSite
Parameters.Label: Parent site
Parameters.HelpText:
The name of the IIS web site to attach the application to. For example, to put the application under the default web site, enter:

    Default Web Site

Parameters.Name: ApplicationPoolName
Parameters.Label: Application pool
Parameters.HelpText: The name of the application pool that the application will run under.

Parameters.Name: BindingProtocols
Parameters.Label: Protocols
Parameters.HelpText: The protocols to use for the application

Parameters.Name: ClientCertificate
Parameters.Label: Client certificate
Parameters.HelpText: _(Require SSL)_ Defines how to handle client certificates if SSL is required.

Parameters.Name: PreloadEnabled
Parameters.Label: Preload Enabled
Parameters.HelpText: If true, sets the application to enable preloading.

Parameters.Name: EnableAnonymous
Parameters.Label: Enable Anonymous authentication
Parameters.HelpText: Whether IIS should allow anonymous authentication

Parameters.Name: EnableBasic
Parameters.Label: Enable Basic authentication
Parameters.HelpText: Whether IIS should allow basic authentication with a 401 challenge.

Parameters.Name: EnableWindows
Parameters.Label: Enable Windows authentication
Parameters.HelpText: Whether IIS should allow integrated Windows authentication with a 401 challenge.

Parameters.Name: SetApplicationPoolSettings
Parameters.Label: Set Application Pool Settings
Parameters.HelpText: If true, this will allow you to set the Application Pool CLR Version, identity using the .NET CLR Version, Identity, Username, and Password parameters.  If false, the other four parameters will be ignored.

Parameters.Name: ApplicationPoolFrameworkVersion
Parameters.Label: Application Pool .NET CLR Version
Parameters.HelpText: The version of the .NET common language runtime that this application pool will use.

DisplaySettings.Octopus.SelectOptions:
v2.0|CLR v2.0 (.NET 2.0, 3.0, 3.5)
v4.0|CLR v4.0 (.NET 4.0, 4.5, 4.6)
No Managed Code

Parameters.Name: ApplicationPoolIdentityType
Parameters.Label: Application Pool Identity
Parameters.HelpText: Which built-in account will the application pool run under.

DisplaySettings.Octopus.SelectOptions:
ApplicationPoolIdentity|Application Pool Identity
LocalService|Local Service
LocalSystem|Local System
NetworkService|Network Service
SpecificUser|Custom user ...

Parameters.Name: ApplicationPoolUsername
Parameters.Label: Application Pool Username
Parameters.HelpText: The Windows/domain account of the custom user that the application pool will run under. Example: YOURDOMAIN\\YourAccount. You will need to ensure that this user has permissions to run as an application pool.

Parameters.Name: ApplicationPoolPassword
Parameters.Label: Application Pool Password
Parameters.HelpText: The password for the custom account given above.
